content.question: "Iam caelum terramque meo sine numine, venti, miscere et tantas audetis tollere moles? Quos ego—sed motos praestat componere fluctus. Post mihi non simili poena commissa luetis. 5Maturate fugam regique haec dicite vestro: non illi imperium pelagi saevumque tridentem, sed mihi sorte datum. Tenet ille immania saxa, vestras, Eure, domos; illa se iactet in aula 10Aeolus et clauso ventorum carcere regnet." Aeneid 1. 133-141 Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question. 1. (A) Identify one and only one literary device found in line 2 (miscere . . . moles) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it. 2. In lines 1-4 (Iam . . . luetis), which three Latin words indicate Neptune’s decision to take control of the situation? 3. In lines 3-4 (Quos . . . luetis), (A) identify two direct objects and (B) translate each in context. 4. In this passage, which two Latin words can be translated as “hurry your escape!”? 5. In this passage, which three Latin words command the delivery of a message to Aeolus? 6. What are the case and use of tridentem (line 6) ? 7. Which two Latin words in this passage are connected by the conjunction et (line 9) ? 8. Identify the two vocative nouns in this passage. 9. (A) Whose prophecy elsewhere in Book 1 tells us that the Trojans will reach Italy? (B) Briefly describe one and only one other thing that is prophesized then.
